content.title: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
content.definition: Vertebrobasilar insufficiency (VBI) is reduced blood flow in the vertebral and basilar arteries causing posterior circulation ischemia, manifesting as vertigo, diplopia, ataxia, drop attacks, and other brainstem/cerebellar symptoms.

anatomy.basilar_artery: Formed by confluence of vertebral arteries at pontomedullary junction
anatomy.posterior_circulation: Supplies brainstem, cerebellum, occipital lobes, thalamus

etiology.atherosclerosis: Most common - typically at vertebral origin
etiology.subclavian_steal: Proximal subclavian stenosis causing retrograde vertebral flow

subclavian_steal_syndrome.mechanism: Proximal subclavian stenosis → arm exercise → retrograde flow in ipsilateral vertebral → posterior circulation ischemia
subclavian_steal_syndrome.diagnosis: BP differential >20 mmHg, duplex shows reversed vertebral flow
subclavian_steal_syndrome.treatment: Subclavian stent or bypass if symptomatic

clinical_presentation.drop_attacks: Sudden falls without loss of consciousness

diagnosis.duplex_ultrasound: Screen vertebral arteries, assess flow direction
diagnosis.mr_angiography: Good for vertebral and basilar arteries
diagnosis.dynamic_studies: With head rotation if bow hunter suspected

medical.first_line: Antiplatelet therapy, statin, risk factor modification
